posts.name: seg9585
posts.cooked:
Over the summer we’ve been running robot demos for our local community.  These demos are running the robot for longer periods of time than a typical match, usually about 10 minutes on, then 5-10 minutes off for cooldown and battery swap. Our VH-109 is attached to our frame mounted to a TPU case with ventilation on 5 out of 6 sides and a single strap securing it to the frame.  It’s powered with the Rev Radio Power Module to RoboRio port (PoE), and DIP switches set to disable PoE for all other ports. After just a couple battery cycles the radio gets extremely hot to the touch, and then fails to connect to laptops around that time.  After waiting for it to cool, removed from the case to lay more freely in the chassis, and the radio runs a little longer before losing connection. After trying this a few times, the radio tripped our 10a fuse.

What do teams do to cool their radios?  Do you have heatsinks/fans attached to its body?  Is it normal for the VH-109 to overheat itself to death?

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
#1: do not put a case on the new radios!  Its literally in the instructions…  they will overheat very quickly!

#2: if you are doing demos, get the fan cooled heat sink for the radio.  Or make one.

At a minimum, zip tie it to an extrusion.  A little grease on the interface can help.  I did that on our permanently mounted field radio.

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked:
The 2.4Ghz radio is also the first feature to shut off under thermal load - are you using that to connect directly to the robot? If yes, definitely add a heatsink and some forced air (fans)… The current TPU case is doing you no favors.

We run the old radio for demos, or connect over 6Ghz because one of our members has a new laptop that can access it. For collaborations across multiple teams, it seems worthwhile to set up a single access point via a heatsunk VH 109 or other solution that avoids 2.4 GHz.

I am surprised to hear about the blown 10 amp, but it should be safe to swap to a 15.

Edit: you can use the power pins on the radio to run a 18?-volt fan without any additional power routing.

Definitely skip the TPU case. For us, mounting the radio to an aluminum 1x2 tube was enough to keep it cool enough to operate in the 6 GHz mode all through a 12 hour joint drive practice/programming session (though with lunch and dinner breaks in the middle there).

posts.name: Zachary
posts.cooked: I recommend reading Vivid-Hosting’s documentation page on the topic of mounting, which covers this topic: https://frc-radio.vivid-hosting.net/overview/mounting-your-radio

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
We have ours mounted in a 3D Printed PLA enclosure, however, we’ve designed it so that the back of the radio directly touches the Aluminum 1x2 that it’s mounted to, allowing for thermal transfer. It’s also open on the top and bottom (for the ports), and has a window for the LEDs.

We’ve had no thermal issues with this setup even through extended practice. We have far more issues with our Limelights getting too hot and having to cool down.

posts.name: Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)
posts.cooked:
The Vivid mounting instructions are very important for conducting away heat.

WCP sells a powered heatsink ( WCP -1822) for the driver station side, but it’s $75 and backordered.

Consider a rig with some of the big 120mm fans from old kits and/or FIRST Choice.  Airflow conducting away heat is clutch!  (Do add a grille though, for the sake of fingers.)

If you don’t have those fans or some cheap 12V fans to rig up, I like these USB-charged clip fans for all sorts of robot needs.  Motors, radio, overheating humans, whatever.

posts.name: seg9585
posts.cooked:
Weldingrod1:

I did that on our permanently mounted field radio.

Permanently mounted — interesting.  Do you bring the entire robot over to the event’s radio programming table?

posts.name: Ryan Blue
posts.cooked:
seg9585:

After trying this a few times, the radio tripped our 10a fuse.

This alone is very disturbing- are you using the aux ports to power anything over POE? The radio should never even come close to pulling 10a on its own.

posts.name: Zach Hoegberg
posts.cooked: I can’t answer for @Weldingrod1 but that is what we did this year on 111/112. We mounted our radios directly to our brainpans, both for the improved heatsinking and because these radios prefers to be mounted low and flat due to their radiation patterns. The one downside to this is it requires access to both the top and bottom of the bot for mounting, which isn’t the end of the world but does mean we prefer to leave it mounted if possible.

posts.name: seg9585
posts.cooked: No, we normally have a limelight connected (without PoE) but due to the high temps, the radio was temporarily removed from the robot and replaced with a different radio (which had no connection issues).  Later, original radio was returned to this demo bot and nothing plugged back into it.  It was working for about 15 minutes doing some light mechanism testing, then we lost connection permanently and discovered the radio powered off and fuse blown. New fuse added and radio replaced with spare (no wiring changes), and we were back in action.

posts.name: tkchan
posts.cooked:
You can also use thermal tape (they sell those for M2.SSD drives) and can use those as a buffer between the radio and the tubing.  I would suggested to mount that to the biggest/longest tube on your robot if you can.  You can also use thermal paste but that gets messy and can spread all over.

something like Amazon.com: Thermal Adhesive Tape (40mmx10 Meters 0.3mm Thickness) Double Side Adhesive Thermal Conductive Tape for Heat Sink of LED Light,PC and More, Electrically Insulated,1 Reel Pack : Electronics

posts.name: Elin Kim
posts.cooked:
Our team has been using thermal pad in between the heatsink with a fan after a little bit of gap. We used it for all three limelights and the radio, and it was very successful. All of the limelights were burning hot before implementing this. Now they are barely even warm. Thermal Pad For Radio: Fan Heat Sink For Limelight: Fan (Can probably find one on amazon) Heat Sink Just make sure to check the operating voltage. We plugged the fan into the lower channel of the PDH and the MPM.

image 872×652 118 KB This is an example of one of our limelight mounts. Other than the mounting area and heatsink, the limelight is barely contacting any other surface. In the middle is the indent for the fan.

image 872×652 118 KB

image 872×652 118 KB

posts.name: FrankJ
posts.cooked:
This year ours is mounted directly on a 1x2x.063 elevator tube. For the 2024 champs we mounted it on a small piece of 1/8 plate. Zero issues with heat. even with extended running. We don’t try to use the 2.4G part. Too many known issues with it. A little heat sink past won’t hurt. We don’t bother with it though.

You don’t need an elaborate heat sink. Al conducts heat away nicely.

posts.name: Benjamin Rowe
posts.cooked: We have ours zip tied to a piece of 2x1 aluminum, and we zip tied a fan to one end to push air through it. It’s a fan from one of the Victor 888s and we power it through the power input weidmuller’s.
